Comment: We are doomed if we take Trumpism in stride and just try to rebuild (*if* we get our country back). Republican institutions and centers of power need to be obliterated. We need to learn from Trump: if you don't like a thing, destroy it quickly and salt the earth. Let your enemies figure out how to pick up the pieces of society.  Coal is destructive to our environment and the industry corrupts our politics. We *could* create a plan to phase out coal over the next 40 years (10 election cycles to reverse course) while subsidizing plants' costs to slowly move to new energy sources. *Or* on the far end of the spectrum, we could seize plants, scrap machinery, collapse mines, and sell the land. Prosecute and imprison CEOs for corruption. Make it a billion dollar investment to start again.  I don't know if that's the best route, but those are the terms we need to think in: the utter destruction of the right; as justice, as punishment, and as insurance against their fascist intent. Imprison Justice Thomas for taking bribes. Impeach the other Trump SC Justices; the insurrectionist traitor doesn't get to put people on the bench. Investigate and imprison insurrectionist elected officials. Prosecute state officials for gerrymandering and other election interference. Tax the fucking churches.  They are destroying this country; it will take decades to rebuild and the costs will be much greater as they upend markets and violate promises. We need to fight back at least as hard.

Comment: So the problem for the rest of the world is not so much that you've got a bad president, but that the systems in your country produced and failed to reign in this bad president.  There are some apologies owed certainly (Canada, Denmark, Greenland, Ukraine), but for most of the rest of the world, words of a president are now pretty meaningless when it's been made clear how much "the next guy" can do a 180 on them.  Instead if you want to convince the rest of the world to get anywhere as tightly integrated with the US again, it's either going to be a _lot_ of time to build up a stable track record again (arguably the last time took you 20+ years, and that's when you were actively rebuilding countries), or systemic reform to prevent this happening again (whether that's more checks on presidents, fairer voting systems for congress, whatever).

Comment: i am not sure if you are following, but 'reconstruction' is the term coined for the changes to southern society implemented by the victorious North in the immediate aftermath of the Civil War, which included stationing Northern troops in Southern cities to protect the black population, giving freed slaves voting rights, and even having some freed slaves hold political office.  Reconstruction was of course very unpopular in the South and when the Democrats won back Congress in the early 1870's following the economic recession caused by the demobilization efforts after the war, Congress defunded Reconstruction efforts, and as part of the corrupt bargain of the 1876 presidential election, reconstruction as a policy formally ended.

Comment: I think the rest of the world was a little too willing to let us just swoop in and handle everything. While it allowed the US to dictate a lot in ‚Äúour‚Äù favor, it gave a false sense of security to our allies and has been largely paid for with declining living standards here in the US. We continue to funnel our wealth towards the ultra-rich and into military spending, while neglecting healthcare and education systems enjoyed by the citizens of other advanced economies. This seems like a reality check that was overdue, and just like having government with only one or two major parties ends up creating dangerous conditions, having a world with only one or two super powers is equally unstable beneath the surface.  To be clear: it‚Äôs a system the US built. I‚Äôm not blaming Europe or anyone else. No single political entity should be in such a position of power that a few thousand voters with a grade school education can dictate the course human history for decades to come.
